title: Turkey ramps up offensive in Syria as Trump officials call pullout of troops 'very big mistake'
text:
Senior US officials have admitted they were “extremely distressed” by the pullback of US troops in northern Syria, calling it a “very big mistake”, as Turkey pressed ahead with its offensive in Syria against Washington’s Kurdish allies.

During a Thursday press briefing, an unnamed senior State Department official said they were “right up there with the Saudis and Bibi Netanyahu” after a reporter asked how the US would address concerns from Washington’s key regional partners that America was “abandoning” its allies in the Middle East.

The Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) - now the target of Turkey's assault - were the US's main ally in fighting against Isis in Syria and lost some 11,000 fighters in the years-long conflict.

The comments came as monitoring groups reported a rising civilian death toll as Turkish forces and their Syrian rebel allies pushed deeper into north-eastern Syria. According to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR), Turkish-backed forces have swept control of 11 villages and encircled two Kurds-held Syrian towns Tal Abyad and Ras al-Ain since President Erdogan launched his offensive on Wednesday to create a “safe zone”.

At least 10 civilians, including three children, have been killed in Syria, while Turkish officials reported at least six civilians, including a 6-month-old baby, were killed by mortar fire from Syria.

As many as 75,000 people have already been displaced, the monitoring group said. Kurdish forces warned Friday they would have to evacuate a camp west of Ras al-Ayn, sheltering more than 7,000 displaced people from other regions of the country and will move a second camp for 13,000 people including families of Isis fighters after both were hit by shelling.

In Washington, Andrea Mitchell from NBC TV channel asked officials during a press briefing to address the worries of regional partners including Saudi Arabia and Israel, pushing officials on why US troops were redeployed in northern Syria and if “the Turkish authorities saw this as a green light”.

The unnamed official replied: “I’m extremely distressed about this, too. I’m right up there with the Saudis and Bibi Netanyahu. This was a very big mistake and it has very big implications for all of our security.”

The official added: “I don’t know of anybody who isn’t upset with it. But I also don’t know why anybody thinks that we gave the Turks a green light.”

President Donald Trump sparked uproar when late Sunday he announced US troops would step aside in north-eastern Syria and not hinder an imminent Turkish cross-border incursion against the Kurds.

The Kurdish-led SDF called the action a “stab in the back” saying they had only just dismantled key military defences along the border Syria-Turkey border as part of a US-penned security arrangement.

SDF leaders said it left them particularly vulnerable when Turkish forces began their assault. The White House and other branches of the government have since denied that it “green-lighted” Mr Erdogan’s offensive.

But Mr Trump appears to have flip-flopped, at one point defending his withdrawal decision by incorrectly asserting the Kurds “didn’t help us in the Second World War”. On Thursday he changed tack, tweeting about mediating a deal between Turkey and the Kurds and possibly imposing sanctions on Turkey.

“I hope we can meditate,” he later said when asked about the options by reporters at the White House.

Turkey reported its first fatality during action in Syria in the offensive which has moved into its third day. The Turkish defence ministry said on Friday that three soldiers were wounded, without providing details.

Funerals were held on Thursday for civilians who were killed by Kurdish fire in south Turkey. ​

Separately, the Turkish defence ministry said that it had killed 277 fights from the Kurdish side. The SOHR, however, has said that number is “hugely inflated” putting the death toll from the SDF and its allies at around 46.

Rights groups have been quick to warn of the potential humanitarian crisis if the fighting continues in north-eastern Syria which is home to some 1.7 million people. The International Committee of The Red Cross warned that there are more than 100,000 people currently being hosted in displacement camps that rely on humanitarian aid and so are at serious risk.

Save The Children, meanwhile, has sounded the alarm about accessing to 8000 foreign children, held in camps for Isis suspects and fighters in the area. Medecins Sans Frontieres warned on Friday, the only public hospital near the frontline has been forced to shut after most of its staff fled from bombings over the past 24 hours.

There are also concerns the battle between Turkey and Kurdish forces will allow the resurgence of the global jihadist group. Russian President Vladimir Putin said Friday that Isis militants held in northeast Syria could escape from jail because of the operation, the Interfax news agency reported.

Kurdish forces at the same time said they were having to move at least one camp holding Isis suspects because of shelling.

The UK, the European Union, most of the US’s allies in the Middle East including Israel, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and the UAE as well as Finland, Denmark and India have joined a chorus of condemnation of Turkey’s military operation.

French officials on Friday signalled the EU may even consider sanctions. Back in Washington dozens of President Trump’s fellow Republicans in the House of Representatives said they would try to introduce legislation to impose sanctions against Turkey.

Mr Erdogan has lashed back warning he would “open the gates” and send 3.6 million Syrian refugees to Europe if the EU and others label the offensive an “invasion.”

European Union Council chief Donald Tusk said Mr Erdogan's remarks were "totally out of place," adding that the EU will never accept "that refugees are weaponised and used to blackmail us."



Mr Tusk urged Turkey to halt the fighting before the conflict triggers a "humanitarian catastrophe".
description: Senior US officials have admitted they were “extremely distressed” by the pullback of US troops in northern Syria, calling it a “very big mistake”, as Turkey pressed ahead with its offensive in Syria against Washington’s Kurdish allies.
